Comment: But they've been electing ghoulsh Republicans for a lot longer than 'since COVID', the governorship has been red since Jeb in '99, and their Class 3 senate seat has been red since '05. House delegations have been majority red since '03. Regardless, Since 1980, they've only gone Blue for pres 3 times, Clinton and Obama twice. They've otherwise gone for Trump 3 times, GW twice, HW twice, and Reagan twice. It may have been in play for Obama, but he won Florida by the thinnest or margins.   This is not a recent phenomenon, and to paint it as such, as if the conservatives suddenly flocked there and changed the state's politics, is a little dismissive of the conservative bend Florida has always had.

Comment: Equating my pragmatic choices about where to live with Nazi sympathizing is both offensive and intellectually dishonest. Everyone prioritizes different issues when making life decisions. I've been transparent about my values and trade-offs, while acknowledging areas where others might choose differently.  Your black-and-white thinking and personal attacks don't foster productive dialogue—they shut it down. You certainly have different priorities, but demonizing people who make different practical life choices than you do isn't advancing any cause. It's just self-righteousness masquerading as moral superiority.  Life requires practical compromises. I vote, I advocate for causes I believe in, but I also need affordable housing and a climate that suits my health and hobbies. By your logic, should I sacrifice my financial stability and quality of life to live only in places with governments I fully agree with? That's not sustainable for most people.   The world isn't divided into heroes who make every life choice based on politics and villains who consider their personal circumstances. Real advocacy comes from building coalitions and understanding different perspectives, not from insulting people who acknowledge the complexity of their choices.
Author: jmcdono362

Comment: You literally said "If I was a woman that could be pregnant, well that would be a whole different topic."  Why does needing to be a woman change anything? You don't have women you care about in your life? And even if you don't, you can't empathize with the millions of women who now do not have a choice or are being told their opinions don't matter and they need to just serve their spouse?  I never said you shared the beliefs of Nazi's, I just said you're ok with them as long as they don't come after you. A Nazi sympathizer isn't part of the Nazi party, supports their ideologies and beliefs, but may not practice them. I implied that you are ok with what this administration is doing as long as it doesn't affect your life. You have already stated that you only "choose your battles" when it directly affects you. So essentially you're willing to hide your head in the sand as long as the sun isn't burning your ass and only choose to be on the right side when it best suits you.  While that is not even on the same level of being a Nazi sympathizer, you definitely have no empathy for others which is along that same vein.

Author: jmcdono362

Comment: You're creating straw men instead of engaging with what I actually said. Your comparison to Nazi sympathizers remains offensive and inappropriate regardless of how you try to qualify it.  When I mentioned pregnancy, I was acknowledging that different people have different priorities based on their circumstances - that's called empathy, not a lack of it. I recognize that reproductive rights would be a more pressing factor for someone who could become pregnant.  I never said I 'only' choose battles that affect me directly. I said I consider where government impacts my life when making living decisions - which is what everyone does to varying degrees. You've twisted this into an extreme caricature that I 'only care when it affects me' and have 'no empathy for others.'  Most people make these kinds of practical trade-offs every day. We choose where to live based on affordability, climate, job opportunities, and proximity to family - not just who the governor is. Your argument essentially demands ideological purity at the expense of personal wellbeing, which isn't sustainable or realistic for most people.  The irony is that by moving somewhere affordable where I can thrive, I'm actually in a better position to support causes I care about than if I were struggling financially in a 'politically perfect' location.  If your goal is to convince others to care more about certain issues, attacking their character and questioning their humanity is perhaps the least effective approach possible.
Author: jmcdono362

Comment: I 100% am engaging with what you said. I quoted everything I have a problem with. I didn't twist anything because "you look at where government directly impacts your life and choose to vote accordingly" and "If I could be a woman that could be pregnant, well that would be a completely different topic." Just because you are not a woman doesn't mean the issues they are facing aren't present or any less important. Of course you should put value in your life and not make sacrifices detrimental to your well being, but only taking action when it directly affects YOUR life, is the same as lacking empathy for others because their lives are being affected.  I'm just calling you out on your action of indifference for others. I am not demanding anything about ideological purity and speaking in absolutes of "either you're with me or against me." I don't have this inflated level of moral superiority and have a need for people to think exactly as me. However I do feel the need to hold those accountable when their indifference affects others. You made the comment, I replied to it. I'm attacking your actions or rather inaction to do something unless it affects your life, and if you feel it's attacking your character then maybe you're starting to understand my point.   As the saying goes, "The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing."
Author: AreYouDumb0rWhat

Comment: You've created a false dichotomy: either I must make every life decision based solely on politics, or I'm complicit with evil. This black-and-white thinking leaves no room for the reality that most people - including passionate advocates - balance multiple factors in their lives.  You have no idea what actions I take to support causes I believe in. Voting, donating, volunteering, and advocacy can happen anywhere - they don't require living in a high-cost state with ideologically aligned leadership.  The Edmund Burke quote you referenced is about standing against evil, not about where someone chooses to live. Many effective change-makers throughout history have made practical compromises in their personal lives while still fighting for their principles.
Author: jmcdono362
